text: So much of the growth in America in the last 30-40 years has been in places without a passionate sense of local government. The suburban sprawl of, say, Phoenix is far different than the sense of localism of Lodi, New Jersey, or Lima, Ohio. (1/2)

text: It was a total lie. But Mitt's staff had written an entire speech claiming he was a (hah!) conservative governor. And Romney himself decided that he had to strengthen the claim. His "severely" line was one of his few conscious missteps in a hyper-controlled campaign.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: The Mitt phrase was “severely conservative.” He was talking to right-wingers at CPAC to demonstrate his conservative bona fides and he ad libbed the word “severely.” It was Mitt’s only change to the written speech and it was maladroit.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: On a serious note (briefly, I promise), I have hated the Democratic political consultant's cliche of "fighting" and "being a fighter" for decades. In 2000, I heard Al Gore give a speech that was little more than a language lesson in the multiple uses of the root word "fight."
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: As all 2020 Democrats position themselves as a "fighter" for families or the middle-class or against racism, I sense that there might be an opening for a candidate who runs on the slogan, "I'm a lover -- not a fighter."

text: A visual memory from covering the 1992 campaign: The Clintons and Gores are on stage at the Grand Ole Opry. Bill and Tipper are exuberantly grooving to the music. Hillary and Al are desperately trying to figure out where is the beat to awkwardly clap their hands to.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Serious point. The Democrats endured three landslides in the 1980s before veering to the center with Clinton in 1992. The political caution that always defined Bill and Hillary was rooted in their collective memories of what it was like to be a Democrat in the 1980s.

text: As a former White House speechwriter, I know the "passion for anonymity" was breached decades ago. Ted Sorensen got credit for JFK's inaugural address and Peggy Noonan for famous Reagan lines. The "Two Americas" speech was a great speech written for a deeply flawed candidate.

text: We have a winner. The earliest use of "likability" in a political context was in the Baltimore Sun in 1916. And, believe it or not, it was describing William Howard Taft. Here's the screen shot:

text: Call me pessimistic, but I suspect that Paul Ryan's Farewell Address will not be remembered like George Washington's or Dwight Eisenhower's ("We must guard against the acquisition of unwarranted influence...by the military-industrial complex)."

text: Quickly, a Super PAC is a political entity aiding a candidate with wink-and-nod separation from the campaign. No legal limitations apply to the size of Super PAC donors. So, in effect, it's letting the mega-wealthy pick the 2020 Democratic nominee.

text: I hope we'll be remembered like the besieged defenders of the Alamo.

text: The first effect that I can see is that sadly it will encourage most major Democratic contenders to set up Jeb-Bush-style Super PACs. Partly because there wasn't a Democratic contest in 2012, Super PACs have never been used in Democratic presidential races.

text: I feel like Sisyphus making this fight about irrelevant polling. And it's still 2018.

text: I like @AmyKlobuchar, so this isn't about her. But, please, please, could we not get caught up in gyrations about Iowa polling preferences when we're more than a year from the caucuses. With so many candidates, everybody will bounce around for months. It's mostly noise.

text: Difference in 2020 is that the Democrats want to win more than they want a candidate with a perfect social revolution score. So unless you think that Sherrod Brown or Gillibrand are the leftwing apocalypse, you're safe. Since they're about as far left as the party is apt to go.

text: All I can say that when Liz Holtzman defeated Manny Celler in a 1972 primary (the closest analogue to @Ocasio2018), the Nixon White House didn't start obsessing over a freshman legislator from Brooklyn. And Holtzman ended up on Judiciary Committee during Watergate.

text: Seriously, I appreciate your answer. Though I think we're light years away from Jeremy Corbyn (not my role model) let alone anything that smacks of social revolution.

text: My critique of Pelosi was always only related to electoral politics. And, fortunately, 2018 was enough of a wave election so she wasn't a drag on House Democrats. I have always admired her skills within the Capitol -- and I think it would be folly to dump her as speaker now.

text: I just got out of a NYC taxi and criminally wished the Sikh driver, “Happy holidays.” If you see Bill O’Reilly, please tell him that I am willing to turn myself in as a repeat offender in the War Against Christmas.

text: It fascinates me how much interest there is in early cheesy measures of candidate popularity  and how comparatively  little interest there is in new DNC rules and the primary calendar.

text: Given the way that TV works, we may have a situation (analogous to Election Night 2018) where the media narrative is wrong in its emphasis for days. That could, for instance, destroy fund-raising for a candidate or two who actually did well on Super Tuesday.

text: Another factor in the slow California count: In 2020, it will be much harder to decipher the results than with the 2018 congressional races. In 2020, many candidates will be bumping up against a 15-percent threshold in dozens of congressional districts creating more tight races.

text: It's a lonely crusade, but I'm glad I have allies. That said, the use of "passing" seems to have dramatically escalated in the last decade or so. Maybe somebody should write a book entitled, "The Death of Dead."
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: A small linguistic issue on a sad day: Why do we persist in using the euphemism "passing" for someone who died? So many public statements are on the "passing" of George Bush. Why not honor the language by noting the "death" of the 41st president instead?
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Three aspects of the Gulf War win my unstinting praise: 1). The restraint, as you note, in not going on to Baghdad; 2). The assembling of a true international coalition (unlike the Iraq War); and 3). Going to the Senate for approval.

text: I suspect that we're closer to agreement here than disagreement. I just wanted to stress that George Bush had his moment with good to excellent press coverage. And his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, was among the best at the job in history.

text: My case that handicappers are under-estimating the Democrats' chances of winning the House. The reason: Virtually all unanticipated, black-swan events would hurt Trump and the GOP. Yesterday was a vivid illustration. My @rollcall column:

text: I know that. But it doesn't forgive bad redesigns built around catering to my supposed needs. Or eliminating bylines on the home page
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Dear @nytimes: I've tried your new home page. I hate it with a passion. I want to see bylines for the main stories. I don't want to scroll through junk to get to sections I like. And I don't want news that supposedly caters to my interests. Can't I keep the old home page? Please?
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: What? I'm ready to march for the option of keeping the old home page.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Scariest headline that I can remember in a long time: "The New York Times home page is changing this week."
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I have long believed that every New Yorker is born with this vocabulary sentence: "Please connect me to your supervisor." The motivation is not race or ethnicity, but the quest for competence in a sea of bureaucratic rigidity.

text: It is hard to find a less sympathetic group of financial losers than bitcoin investors, other than maybe those who buy gold via ads on Fox News.

text: Borgen is wonderful. It may be the best single TV series ever about the realities and tradeoffs of politics. I still miss it.

author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Why is Congress placing reasonable restrictions on the president's ability to punish political enemies an endorsement of an uncontrolled bureaucracy?
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I know, I know. But even with Obama in the White House, Congress was reluctant to write a new resolution authorizing war against ISIS. The last 40 years have been a consistent story of Congress shouting, "Not my table" on most matters of national security.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: The risks of inaction never seem to occur to them. That said, Republicans have been particularly craven since Trump's inauguration.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I think that most members of Congress, regardless of party, have been brought up on deference to a president on big things like national security. Never forget the fear of members of Congress about being responsible for anything that could go wrong.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I don't think any of us have enough garments in our wardrobe to deal with the over-reactions to come. It almost makes me long for the days when there were few polls and political reporters mostly depended on the purported wisdom of county chairmen.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Just a reminder: Congress has the power to change or limit a president's power over security clearances. Anything that Trump does unilaterally could, in theory, be overturned by our elected representatives. Just another area where Congress has given a president too much power.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Sorry, but we disagree on this. Too many variables (compulsory voting, public funding, political tradition) are different in Australia. And remember what I wrote was a 1000-word column — and not a cross-cultural academic paper.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Sorry. It was there 15 minutes ago. It has indeed somehow vanished. But it is the normal boilerplate at the bottom on my columns. I will have it corrected on Monday.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: While I'm not certain, i don't think that ranked-choice voting is an issue that has engaged anyone at the Brennan Center up until now.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Here's the quote from the Brennan Center at the bottom of my column: "The views expressed are the author's own and not necessarily those of the Brennan Center for Justice." Maybe you saw the column reprinted on the Washington Monthly website which may not have included the line.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Let me repeat again. I am a fellow at the Brennan Center, but my views are my own. I do not speak for the Brennan Center nor do I make policy for them. That was made clear in a disclosure that went with the column.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: My point is that the evidence is far from conclusive since I reject cross-cultural comparisons because of different campaign finance systems and political cultures. And a few mayoral elections do not, for me, represent a major test. Obviously, you disagree, hence the impasse.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I admire you your certainty.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Final word, I was writing for myself and not as an official spokesman for the Brennan Center. I believe it says that in the fine print that accompanied the column.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Still deeply skeptical about the effects on political parties and the promotion of self-funders. But I could be wrong and I did enjoy our exchange.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Among the many problems with so promiscuously quoting Rudy, there is this important one: Giuliani has a terrible track record in predicting what Trump will do or say. As a result, Rudy's comments don't change the odds of pardons before Mueller is done.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: You may be right. But even though it isn't your intention, I have been struck by how many advocates of ranked-choice voting start talking about third parties and independent candidates. That's why it (rather than voter equity) was the focus of my column.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Happy to talk in person in the weeks ahead. If I sounded cranky at any point in the exchange, it mostly reflected from frustrations with Twitter and 280 characters.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Why do I think that the arguments for steel production in the Chinese People's Daily and the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette might have been a tad different?
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Okay, I'm defeatist. Now, will you admit that we're doomed to disagree.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Both reforms reflect the goo-goos' distaste for political parties, even if they are different remedies. And remember this was a journalistic column, which dealt with California in a few paragraphs, and not a scholarly monograph.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Our key difference: Larry Diamond writes approvingly "RCV opens up the electoral process to independents and third-party candidates." He thinks that's a good thing. I think the deliberate undermining of political parties is a bad thing.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: We are doomed to disagree on this. I'm not persuaded by the evidence. And you are. Can't see a solution on Twitter to this impasse.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Problem with cross-cultural examples is that Australia and Ireland have totally different campaign finance systems and political traditions.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Afraid we disagree. The biggest obstacle to self-funders running as independents is the "wasted vote problem." Take that away -- and they'll be many more self-funders, I believe. But the important thing to remember is that there ain't much evidence either way.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: So important to remember that Watergate was a gradual unraveling of the Nixon presidency. So much mistaken mythology that it was Woodward and Bernstein and then -- voila -- Nixon resigned.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Sorry, there was also a NY Times editorial that I cited in the piece. And the Nobel-Prize winners were also talking about ranked-choice voting.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: We have found a point of agreement: Had there been ranked-choice voting in Florida in 2000, I admit that all those Jewish Pat Buchanan voters probably would have picked Al Gore as their second choice.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: As I indicate in quoting the NY Times and LA Times editorials, the arguments made by proponents of both reforms sounded eerily similar. I realize that they are different systems, but they were both powered by a high-minded worship of moderation.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Seriously, thanks for the update on "FUD." And sorry that I remain skeptical that mechanical fixes in the voting system will solve significant problems in American democracy.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I have no idea what “FUD” but I assume it’s not complimentary. Sorry we are doomed to disagree.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I hate to break it to you, but I am a journalist who operates without equations or academic citations in my columns. There was somehow also a lack of equations in the NY Times editorial that I quoted.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Forgive me for judging ranked-choice voting based on the arguments that proponents like the NY Times edit page made stressing that it would encourage moderation. You should make sure that proponents of the reform you favor read your papers.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Could be. I don't know the law on this.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Sorry. I put in all the equations, but my editors took them out. Seriously, I didn't refer to it for both reasons of space and also because I was more concerned with the effects on political parties than claims that ranked-choice voting was somehow more equitable.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Twitter is a terrible vehicle for serious discussions. But I worry that (beyond Trump) this would create an American system with weak parties and self-funding rich people dominating everywhere.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Big question: If the Mueller report were to be sent to Congress at the end of the year, could a 2019 Democratic majority in the House release the report to the public even if the GOP Senate was militantly opposed?
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: You have to understand American campaign finance system. Getting rid of the "wasted vote" problem would encourage a proliferation of rich self-funders to run for president as independents. I don't consider that healthy.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Mostly agree. But as you know, the number of state conventions that decide anything has been declining for decades. Often in states like Connecticut, convention endorsements can be over-ridden if candidates petition themselves onto primary ballot.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I agree on both Twitter and getting together in person. And I haven't even heard from my friend @RickHertzberg on this column.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Sorry that I'm at odds with Australian political scientists. But I wonder how many of them understand the American system of political finance, such as it is.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: In practice, we no longer have a majority standard at national conventions. Look at the polls in April 2016 saying that overwhelming majority of GOP voters would give nomination to candidate with most primary votes even if he didn't have a majority.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Not sure that Twitter is the best vehicle to discuss this at length. But my underlying point about parties in a US context was entwined with our campaign finance laws that give a big edge to self-funding independents.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: You may be right. But we really haven't had the ranked-choice ballot tested in, say, a 12-way congressional primary. The primaries in Maine last Tuesday were limited (none for the US Senate) and pretty straight forward.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Forgive me. I was awkwardly trying to anticipate.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Also, SF example doesn't really help since California doesn't used ranked-choice voting, so the local ballot is simpler.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Maybe. But the Maine ballot was pretty simple this year with many races (US Senate, for example) without contested primaries. Wait until Maine gets 10-way primaries for a bunch of offices -- and then we'll know more.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: One problem with the Australian comparison is that America (thank you Supreme Court) allows self-funders to spend unlimited money running as independents. You can't separate instant run-offs from our current system of campaign finance.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Both efforts, though, scorn political parties. I remain skeptical that mechanical changes like instant run-offs can spur moderation. And I also fear that such a change will spur rich-guy self-funders running as independents.
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: I offer a skeptical look at ranked-choice voting and other well-intentioned reforms that denigrate political parties in this @BrennanCenter column:
author: MrWalterShapiro

text: Just curious if you know the identity of the last sitting Democratic senator from Connecticut who was defeated for reelection. If you don't know, it was Augustine Lonergan in 1938. Somehow I wouldn't bet against Chris Murphy.
